member.name: T:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl
member.summary: Represents a WPF control that wraps an Awesomium web view. You can use it to embed Awesomium directly in your WPF application without any additional work.
member.remarks:
You can create an instance of this class by directly invoking the default constructor (either by dropping it in your designer surface, through XAML or from code). You do not need to explicitly create an instance of a web view through . WebControl takes care of this internally.
Note that it is safe to use this control in a design environment for layout and configuration purposes. and the underlying web view are only instantiated during runtime.
The Role of the Property: In addition to its regular meaning, the property indicates if internal asynchronous rendering of the underlying web-view, is currently enabled.
All rendering in the underlying web-view is actually done asynchronously in a separate process and so the page is usually continuously rendering internally. Setting to false, will temporarily pause rendering.
The Role of the Property: A is considered invalid when it is:
Crashed (see ).
When crashed, this control will attempt to recreate its underlying view. For details, see: .
Prematurely destroyed (see and ).
Not properly instantiated. This means that something went wrong during instantiation of either the (if this is the first created) or of the underlying web-view.
Developers should always check this property before calling members implemented by this . Trying to access the underlying web-view when it is not alive, can throw an .
For more details, refer to the documentation of this control's members.
also returns false when the control is shown in a designer. The Awesomium and the underlying web-view, are only instantiated during runtime.

example.code:
<Window x:Name="webWindow" x:Class="StarterSample.MainWindow" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml" xmlns:awe="http://schemas.awesomium.com/winfx" xmlns:data="http://schemas.awesomium.com/winfx/data" xmlns:core="http://schemas.awesomium.com/core" WindowStartupLocation="CenterScreen" Title="{Binding Title, ElementName=webControl}" Height="700" Width="1200"> <Window.Resources> <awe:WebSessionProvider x:Key="webSession" DataPath=".\Cache"> <core:WebPreferences ShrinkStandaloneImagesToFit="False" SmoothScrolling="True" /> </awe:WebSessionProvider>
<awe:UrlConverter x:Key="UrlConverter" /> </Window.Resources> <awe:WebDialogsLayer> <Grid> <Grid.RowDefinitions> <RowDefinition Height="30"/> <RowDefinition /> <RowDefinition Height="25" /> </Grid.RowDefinitions> <DockPanel LastChildFill="True"> <Button Content="Back" Width="60" Command="{x:Static NavigationCommands.BrowseBack}" CommandTarget="{Binding ElementName=webControl}"/> <Button Content="Forward" Width="60" Command="{x:Static NavigationCommands.BrowseForward}" CommandTarget="{Binding ElementName=webControl}"/> <Button Content="Reload" Width="60" Command="{x:Static NavigationCommands.Refresh}" CommandParameter="False" CommandTarget="{Binding ElementName=webControl}"/> <Button Content="Home" Width="60" Command="{x:Static NavigationCommands.BrowseHome}" CommandTarget="{Binding ElementName=webControl}"/> <TextBox FontSize="16" Padding="3,0" VerticalContentAlignment="Center" TextWrapping="NoWrap" Text="{data:SourceBinding webControl}" /> </DockPanel> <awe:WebControl Grid.Row="1" x:Name="webControl" IsTransparent="True" WebSession="{Binding Source={StaticResource webSession}}" Source="{Binding Source, ElementName=webWindow}"/> <TextBlock Grid.Row="2" VerticalAlignment="Center" Padding="3" TextWrapping="NoWrap" TextTrimming="CharacterEllipsis" Text="{Binding TargetURL, ElementName=webControl, Converter={StaticResource UrlConverter}}"/> </Grid> </awe:WebDialogsLayer> </Window>

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.CreateGlobalJavascriptObject(System.String)
member.summary: Create a global JavaScript object that will persist between all loaded pages, for the lifetime of this instance.
member.param: The name of the object as it will appear in JavaScript.
member.returns: If this call succeeds, the returned will be of type 'Object' (see ). You can check the reason why the call failed by calling after this method.
member.remarks:
Global Objects can only contain the following JavaScript types as properties:
Number
String
Array
Null
Other Global Objects
Undefined
Global Objects will retain any custom methods that are registered (see ).
To create a child global-object, you should specify the full name with dot-notation for example: parentObject.childObject.
The parent object should exist before attempting to make any children.
You can create global Javascript objects on a view, as soon as it goes live. ( is true). On technology specific WebControls, you should wait for the event. components go live immediately after creation.

The operation is not supported on a Developer Tools Inspector view (see: ).
Javascript calls are not supported when Javascript is disabled (see: ).
The member is called from inside a synchronous Javascript Execution Context.
The specified is reserved. It either represents an HTML DOM object, or an object variable already available in the page. Use after , to obtain this object.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.SaveImageAt(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Attempt to download an image at the specified coordinates in the page. This is meant to be used with .
member.param: An x-coordinate within an image in the page.
A y-coordinate within an image in the page.
member.remarks:
All coordinates should be localized to the view. All values are in pixels, the origin (0,0) begins at the top-left corner of the view, positive values are "down" and positive values are "right".
This method will attempt to download the image at the specified coordinates, directly from the server. In technology-specific WebControls, a Save As dialog will be shown in response to the download request.
If you are using the headlessÂ component, you will have to handle to either display a dialog or silently save the resource. More appropriately in this case, you should assign your implementation of to , to handle UI related events including .
member.returns: true if a download operation for an image at the specified coordinates, was successfully triggered; false otherwise.
member.exception: The member is called on an invalid view. (See: )

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.OnIsEnabledChanged(System.Windows.DependencyPropertyChangedEventArgs)
member.summary: Maintains the relationship between the control's enabled status and internal asynchronous rendering (see ).
member.remarks:
In addition to its regular meaning, the property indicates if internal asynchronous rendering of the underlying web-view, is currently active.
All rendering in the underlying web-view is actually done asynchronously in a separate process and so the page is usually continuously rendering internally. Setting to false, will temporarily pause rendering.
Inheritors can override , then set manually if they want to disconnect internal asynchronous rendering, from the control's enabled status.
Note that this method is provided by the WPF so that you can control the relationship between the control's enabled status and internal asynchronous rendering (see ). It does not trigger the event. The event is fired by the .NET Framework before this method is called.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.FocusView
member.summary: Notifies the current page that it has gained focus.
member.remarks: You will need to call this to gain text-box focus, among other things. (If you fail to ever see a blinking caret when typing text, this is why.)

remarks.note: handles this internally. Inheritors do not need to call this method unless they implement custom logic.
For performance reasons, no validity check is performed when calling protected members. Inheritors should perform any such checks (see ), before calling these members.

member.summary: Occurs when an is requested by the view. Usually, every time the size of the view changes. You should return your own implementation here.
member.remarks:
When is called, reflects the previously assigned instance. If your surface is capable of handling resizing, you can keep on using the same instance on multiple calls.
When is called for the first time, returns the assigned to the view using or, if no instance has been previously specified, the default assigned to the view by Awesomium.NET. This is either a (for instances) or a technology specific .
If you are using an instance capable of handling changes in size, you should better use to assign your surface. This surface will be used with multiple calls of and it should be able to handle changes in size during . In this scenario, you can ignore the event.

member.name: E:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.InitializeView
member.summary: Occurs when the underlying web-view of a WebControlis about to be instantiated and wrapped or, for child views created in response to a , the native view assigned to the NativeView property of a WebControl, is about to be wrapped.
member.remarks:
This is the last moment for setting any of the following properties, on a WebControl:
Technology
Properties
WPF
Windows Forms
These properties are implemented as read-write properties on WebControls and can only be set before the underlying web-view of a WebControl is created, or a previously created native view is wrapped (see ).
Right after this event is fired, the WebControl goes live ( is set to true) and these properties can no longer be changed.
Attempting to set some of the above properties after a WebControl is live, is usually silently ignored but may also throw an exception. For details, refer to the documentation of the properties.
This event is not fired on instances. A component goes live immediately at creation.

This event is not fired on instances. A component goes live immediately after creation.

member.name: E:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.WindowClose
member.summary: Occurs when Javascript in the page calls window.close.
member.remarks:
You can ignore this event, or respond depending on the current context. For example, if the page is open in the main window of an application or a tab, browsers display a confirmation dialog asking the user if he wants to acknowledge the page's request.
If the page is open in a popup window, browsers usually respect the request and close the popup window, without any confirmation from the user.

On any instance, right after a call to .

member.name: E:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.JavascriptRequest
member.summary: Occurs when a JavaScript client sends a management request through (such as , etc.).
member.remarks:
The request sent is identified by .
A request token can be passed by JavaScript clients to the native application and it's received through
Unless the request originates from a page that has been created by the application (such as pages provided though a ), applications should be careful when handling management requests. For example, a command asks from the native application to exit immediately. The is provided so that native applications can validate such requests.

member.name: E:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.JavascriptMessage
member.summary: Occurs when a JavaScript client sends a message through or .
member.remarks:
and the asynchronous , can be used instead of creating and binding to custom methods of a global JavaScript object created with .
Unlike regular synchronous custom JavaScript methods created by the managed application through or using the Dynamic Language Runtime (DLR), allows callers to pass JavaScript objects to the array, even though the method is called synchronously (see Synchronous & Asynchronous API).
JavaScript objects passed to are being serialized, any function members (methods) are stripped out and they are deserialized to the hosting application as local JSObjects. Nevertheless, the objects are still passed by reference. Any changes applied to passed objects in the handler of a event, will be reflected back to the original remote instances when returns.
Function members (methods) of objects passed to , are being stripped out when the object is passed to the hosting application (calling them from the hosting application would cause a deadlock). However this does not affect the original client-side instances.
JavaScript objects passed to , are serialized and deserialized using JSON. Objects whose structure includes a circular reference, cannot be passed.

member.name: E:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.ShowCreatedWebView
member.summary: Occurs when an creates a new child web-view instance (usually the result of window.open or an external link).
member.remarks:
occurs when an instance creates a new child view (usually the result of window.open, clicking on a link with target="_blank" or submitting a form with target="_blank").
It is your responsibility to wrap and display this new view in your application.
The event must always be handled in your application to wrap views created by Awesomium in response to users clicking a link or JavaScript window.open calls.
If you don't handle this event, the unused web-view instance will be immediately destroyed.
There are a number of facts you need to take into consideration, before taking the appropriate actions in response to a event. The following list presents these facts and some general suggestions:
The created child view, has the same type (see ) and is assigned to the same session (see ) as its parent (opener) view. Therefore, you should not attempt to set these properties if you are wrapping the new child view with a technology specific WebControl.
In order to maintain the relationship with their parent view, child views execute and render under the same process (awesomium_process) as their parent view. If for any reason the child process crashes, all views related to it will be affected.
If is fired as a result of a Javascript window.open, will be true. In this scenario, you should always wrap the created child view instance (), to maintain the parent-child window relationship (the child page can access the parent through the window.opener property; the parent can manipulate the child through the window object returned from the window.open call, which is why window.open was most probably used in the first place).
If is fired as a result of an HTML form with target="_blank" and method="post", will be true. In this scenario, you should always wrap the created child view instance (), to allow POST data be properly passed.
When or are false, it most possibly indicates that the event is the result of a user clicking on a link with target="_blank". Since maintaining a parent-child relationship is not important in this scenario, you should cancel the event by setting to true (this tells the core to destroy the unused web-view instance), then create a new (using ) or WebControl and navigate to the provided , if any. This allows you to take advantage of the isolated process architecture of Awesomium and let each view be rendered in a separate process.
Failing to cancel the event when you are not wrapping the new child view instance, will keep the native instance alive until the is shut down. This can result in numerous unused views being spawned, but never actually used.
When or is true, navigation to the , if any, is already queued on the created child view. Therefore you should not attempt to set the when you are wrapping the child view, as this would again break the parent-child relationship (window.opener on the child page and the window object returned from the window.open call on the parent page, will be rendered invalid) or prevent passing POST data to the server respectively.
Also note that since navigation to the , if any, has already started by the moment the child view is wrapped, will not be fired for the main frame of the new instance.
Navigation to the , if any, is blocked on the created child view, when and are false. As applications will generally choose to cancel the event and create a new instance to navigate to the target URL (or even choose to navigate to the target URL on the same instance that fired the event), Awesomium.NET does this to prevent false hits to the target URL, that would have occurred by the time the event handler returns and the unused child view instance, is destroyed. What's more, users may also implement and cancel requests to new views that are the result of JavaScript window.open (see ). Therefore, if your application chooses to wrap the created child view even though it is most possibly the result of a user clicking on a link with target="_blank" or navigation to the target URL has already been canceled by an (see ), you should in this scenario only, after wrapping the child view, set the property to to resume navigation to the target URL.
Applications can occasionally choose to wrap a child view even when is false or is true, if they want to apply a single process architecture where all new views created will be rendered by the same awesomium_process.
When is true, returns a valid, initialized instance. This may be initialized to default values if is false, or reflect the specs specified to the window.open call, if is true.
If is true, applications should generally wrap and present the native view in a new popup application window. This window should have the size and location specified in , if this is not empty. They should also respect the rest of the specs available through , when creating the new application window that will host the child view.
When is true, is always also true.
will only be true, if specs were specified to the window.open call. These can be standard specs such as width=400,height=400,menubar=no, only user defined, non-standard specs such as background=black or a combination of both. These specs are available through the property.
If only user defined, non-standard specs were specified to the window.open call, will be true. In this scenario, if your application does not recognize user defined, non-standard specs, it can ignore the value of all together and wrap the new child view in a regular new application window, tab or control.
When is true, returns an array of , representing the upload data passed to the using POST.
Finally note that only an empty name parameter or a _blank target attribute specified as the name parameter in a window.open call or in a link or form, will fire a event. Other target attributes (such as _top), passed to either a window.open call, a link or a form, are handled by Awesomium internally.
Several members of , may not return valid values if Javascript is disabled. For details, read the documentation of: .
Given the facts and suggestions presented before, if your application is about to wrap the created child view, the following table shows the methods available, to wrap the created child view using any of the Awesomium.NET web-view components:
Technology
Method and Notes
Core
Pass to to wrap the new view with a .
For windowed views (see ), you should now assign a . Offscreen views have a assigned by default but depending on your application's design, you may have to assign a new by either monitoring the event, or setting the property.
Resize the to match its container.
WPF
Create a new and assign to the property.
Note that you should assign the created child view instance to , before the goes live (see ), or else the will create and wrap a new, underlying web-view instance. The appropriate way to do this, is either by binding the property in XAML (see examples in the Awesomium.NET Samples solution available with the SDK), or by monitoring the event, the last fired before the control goes live.
Resize the or its container.
Windows Forms
Create a new and assign to the property.
Note that you should assign the created child view instance to , before the goes live (see ), or else the will create and wrap a new, underlying web-view instance. The appropriate way to do this, is either by assigning the property right after the is created (see examples in the Awesomium.NET Samples solution available with the SDK),or by monitoring the event, the last fired before the control goes live.
Resize the or its container.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.Presenter
member.summary: Gets or sets an presentation control that will receive requests for UI related events.
member.remarks:
Members of the interface are used by views to propagate UI related requests that they cannot handle by themselves. For example, the windowlessÂ does not handle any UI related events itself. If an has been assigned to the property, those requests will be propagated to the presentation control, unless previously handled by a relative event handler.
When used with an offscreenÂ , an instance of that also implements , will be used as the view's default surface, as long as it has been assigned to immediately after the creation of the .
Usage in WPF The interface is extensively used in WPF. presentation controls are used in the visual tree when styling a WPF . These can be custom WPF surfaces implementing (for offscreen views) or any other control providing custom presentation of a instance.
When the custom control is added to the visual tree and loaded for presentation, the instance (typically, a WPF ) uses the interface to communicate with the presentation control.
Awesomium.Windows.Controls already provides 2 such presenters:
Presentation Control Usage (by the default style)
Used when is set to (default). This is an component that uses 100% WPF logic to copy the view's pixel buffer to a bitmap that it then renders for presentation.
This is an that is used when is set to . For more details, read the documentation of .

member.name: P:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.ContextMenuPageItemsArrayRecourceKey

remarks.para: You can use this resource key to override the items in the context menu of a , that are visible when you right-click on a page that has no selection and no keyboard focus.
remarks.note: If you only wish to add items to the predefined ones, keep in mind that you have to redefine all the items of the array.

member.example:
The default-predefined array in XAML is:
<x:Array x:Key="{x:Static awe:WebControl.ContextMenuPageItemsArrayRecourceKey}" Type="{x:Type DependencyObject}"> <MenuItem Command="BrowseBack" /> <MenuItem Command="BrowseForward" /> <MenuItem Command="Refresh" /> <Separator /> <MenuItem Command="Print" /> <Separator /> <MenuItem Command="SelectAll" /> </x:Array>

remarks.note: If you only wish to add items to the predefined ones, keep in mind that you have to redefine all the items of the array.

member.example:
The default-predefined array in XAML is:
<x:Array x:Key="{x:Static awe:WebControl.ContextMenuInputItemsArrayRecourceKey}" Type="{x:Type DependencyObject}"> <MenuItem Command="Copy" /> <MenuItem Command="Cut" /> <MenuItem Command="Paste" /> <Separator /> <MenuItem Command="SelectAll" /> </x:Array>

member.name: P:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.IsDisposed
member.summary: Gets if this wrapper and its underlying web-view, have been disposed.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.IsLive
member.summary: Gets if the native web-view, is alive.
member.returns:
A value indicating if the native web-view, is alive. False indicates that the native web-view is:
Crashed (see ).
When crashed, technology specific WebControls will attempt to recreate the underlying view. For details, see: .
Prematurely destroyed (eg, using ).
Not properly instantiated. This means that something went wrong during instantiation of either the (if this is the first view created) or of the native web-view.
member.remarks:
Developers should always check this property before calling members. Trying to access the native web-view when it is not alive, can throw an .
For more details, refer to the documentation of view members.
This property also returns false when technology specific WebControls are shown in a designer. The Awesomium and the native web-view, are only instantiated during runtime.

example.code:
Private Sub ToolStripButton2_Click( sender As Object, e As EventArgs ) Handles ToolStripButton2.Click If Not m_WebControl.IsLive Then Return
m_WebControl.GoForward() End Sub

member.name: P:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.IsRendering
member.summary: Gets if internal asynchronous rendering is currently enabled.
member.remarks:
All rendering is actually done asynchronously in a separate process and so the page is usually continuously rendering internally.
This property is automatically updated by monitoring the control's enabled status and it should not be manually set. The update occurs in .
Inheritors can override , then set manually if they want to disconnect internal asynchronous rendering, from the control's enabled status.

member.summary: Gets the identifier for the corresponding child-process hosting this instance.
member.remarks:
May return 0 if the instance has crashed or there is no rendering process currently associated (see ).
This is not a unique identifier for the instance. A child, rendering process can host more than one views (see ).
This does not correspond to the system-wide id of the associated (PID). It's an Awesomium-specific identifier.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControl.RenderProcess
member.summary: Gets the rendering process associated with this instance. This represents the executing awesomium_process or the one specified through at initialization.
member.remarks:
This may not be initialized until some time after the view is actually created (when we receive the first IPC message from the child-process). It may also return null (Nothing in Visual Basic), is there is no rendering process associated yet (see ) or the process has crashed (see ).
The associated will be terminated when this instance is disposed and destroyed.
The default priority of the , is . This may be automatically lowered to when is false.
In a technology-specific WebControl, and the priority of the , are associated to the control's enabled status.
Actions that may corrupt the execution state of the rendering process, will directly affect view's web content rendering. Manually killing this process, will mark the view as crashed (see ).

Level Title Value
"None" only reflects the page's title, if any.
"Normal" reflects the page's title as well as "Error" and "Crashed" status.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebDialogsLayer
member.summary: Represents a decoration layer used to display predefined dialogs (such as JavaScript and Login dialogs).
member.remarks:
When you are using a in default rendering mode ( is set to Offscreen) or when you are using a with a , dialogs such as JavaScript and Login are shown in a layer over the .
If you are using more than one views (WebControls or WebViewPresenters), this has certain implications as some dialogs are Awesomium-wide modal and while they are visible, users cannot interact with any other . What's more, if a view is currently not visible (like if it is in a tab of a that is currently not selected), users cannot see that a dialog is opened over the hidden view and they cannot explain why they cannot interact with some other view currently visible.
A allows you to wrap a container control that is always visible and contains one or more views, with a decorator that will display the dialogs of all views making sure they are always visible and preventing users from interacting with other views while a dialog is open.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates wrapping a with some WebControls, with a . Dialogs launched from any , will be displayed by the over the , preventing users from interacting with anything under the , until the dialog is closed.
<Window x:Class="WpfApplication1.MainWindow" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml" xmlns:awe="http://schemas.awesomium.com/winfx" xmlns:data="http://schemas.awesomium.com/winfx/data" Height="480" Width="640"> <awe:WebDialogsLayer DialogsStyle="Classic"> <TabControl> <TabItem Header="{Binding Title, ElementName=webControl1}"> <awe:WebControl x:Name="webControl1" Source="http://awesomium.com/" /> </TabItem> <TabItem Header="{Binding Title, ElementName=webControl2}"> <awe:WebControl x:Name="webControl2" Source="http://google.com/" /> </TabItem> </TabControl> </awe:WebDialogsLayer> </Window>

member.remarks:
Attach and set this property on a or to specify the delay time (in milliseconds) for a press-and-hold gesture to cancel a touch manipulation and promote touch to mouse events. The default 1000 (1 second).
To completely disable pres-and-touch, use the attached property.
The minimum allowed value for , is 10 milliseconds.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebPopupMenu
member.summary: Predefined stylable drop-down (popup) menu used by the in response to .
member.remarks:
There are multiple ways to customize, override or block the default drop-down (popup) menu of a . These are described in the following list:
Action Result
Redefine a application resource, using the as its key.
Substitutes the default drop-down (popup) menu with the one of your own. You can then optionally specify your own Style for it.
Handle the event and set the property to true.
This will block the default drop-down (popup) menu from displaying. You can then manually display your own drop-down (popup) menu.

member.summary: Extends the .
member.remarks:
When you are using a , the items added to the collection, will be instances of this subclass.
Note that if your WPF application uses other instances (such as ), may end up containing both core instances, as well as WPF specific instances. If your UI provides templates only for the WPF , other instances will not be recognized. This however can be useful as your application would normally not want to visualize download operations initiated from a windowlessÂ wrapper, such as the .

member.name: T:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebControlContextMenu
member.summary: Predefined stylable context menu used by .
member.remarks:
There are multiple ways to customize, override or block the default context menu of a . These are described in the following list:
Action Result
Redefine a application resource, using the as its key.
Completely substitutes the default context menu. You should bind the property to the property, to access the . You can later use the provided through to update the state of the menu's items.
Assign your own context menu to the property. Same as before but in this case you should provide your own display context data.
Redefine one or more arrays of menu items in your application resources, using the following keys (depending on the group you wish to substitute or change):
Substitutes or edits specific menu items' groups, that are visible according to the current context. For more details, read the documentation of the resource keys.
Handle the event and set the property to true. This will prevent the default context menu from displaying. You can then programmatically display your own context menu.

member.summary: Gets the maximum size of memory in bytes that this instance should use to cache resources in memory. Specify 0, to prevent caching resources in-memory.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Windows.Data.DirectoryDataSourceProvider.Preload
member.summary: Gets or sets if resources from the directory and its subdirectories, should be pre-loaded to memory.
member.remarks:
will load all the available resources from the directory and its subdirectories to memory, ignoring files with the specified and until it reaches the specified .
This operation is performed asynchronously and the can still be used while files are being loaded in memory. When pre-loading completes, is fired synchronously.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Windows.Data.DirectoryDataSourceProvider.IsInMemory
member.summary: Gets if this is an in-memory data source provider.
member.remarks:
In-memory instances, cache the requested files in memory either when they are first requested, or by using . In subsequent requests for the same resource, the loads the resource from memory instead of reading from disk. This can significantly improve performance.
An in-memory will stop caching resources to memory when the specified has been reached.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Windows.Data.SourceBinding
member.summary: Represents a markup extension that binds the property of a WPF , to the property of a view (usually a ), manipulates the bound and manages its relationship with the source instance.
member.remarks:
Besides binding the property of a WPF , to the property of a web-view, the class significantly simplifies your code by monitoring user input and maintaining the proper relationship of the bound with the source instance.
The following list summarizes the features provided by , when applied to the property of a WPF :
Keeps the contents of the updated with the textual representation of the current .
When the user updates the contents of the , explicitly updates the source property, only when the Return key is being pressed.
Applies proper value conversion. For example, a nullÂ property will be presented as about:blank and any string will be properly parsed before passed to the instance.
Value conversion is provided through a , that can also be used with other bindings in your application.
Monitors the appropriate events and applies the required logic so that your behaves as an address-box. For example, when the gets keyboard focus, all contents are automatically selected; when it looses keyboard focus, the contents are updated to reflect the current value of .
Manages focus toggling of the bound and the source instance, whenever necessary.
Prevents updating the contents of the bound , when it has keyboard focus.
The utilizes the WPF weak event model to monitor events. This prevents potential memory leaks.
Weak event handling support is provided through the and the implementation of . The is available for you to use anywhere else in your project.
member.example:
The following example presents the usage of , in XAML.
<Window x:Class="WpfApplication1.MainWindow" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml" xmlns:awe="http://schemas.awesomium.com/winfx" xmlns:data="http://schemas.awesomium.com/winfx/data" Height="480" Width="640"> <Window.Title> <Binding Path="Title" ElementName="webControl" StringFormat="Awesomium Simple WPF Sample - {0}"/> </Window.Title> <Grid> <Grid.RowDefinitions> <RowDefinition Height="Auto" /> <RowDefinition /> </Grid.RowDefinitions> <Grid x:Name="toolbarContainer" MinHeight="30"> <Grid.ColumnDefinitions> <ColumnDefinition Width="Auto" /> <ColumnDefinition Width="Auto" /> <ColumnDefinition Width="Auto" /> <ColumnDefinition Width="Auto" /> <ColumnDefinition /> </Grid.ColumnDefinitions> <Button Margin="2" Padding="3" Command="BrowseBack" CommandTarget="{Binding ElementName=webControl}"> Back </Button> <Button Grid.Column="1" Margin="2" Padding="3" Command="BrowseForward" CommandTarget="{Binding ElementName=webControl}"> Forward </Button> <Button Grid.Column="2" Margin="2" Padding="3" Command="Refresh" CommandParameter="False" CommandTarget="{Binding ElementName=webControl}"> Refresh </Button> <Button Grid.Column="3" Margin="2" Padding="3" Command="BrowseHome" CommandTarget="{Binding ElementName=webControl}"> Home </Button> <!-- Address box. --> <TextBox x:Name="addressBox" Grid.Column="4" Margin="3" VerticalContentAlignment="Center" Text="{data:SourceBinding webControl}"/> </Grid> <!-- WebControl --> <awe:WebControl x:Name="webControl" Grid.Row="1" BorderThickness="0,1,0,0" BorderBrush="Gray" Source="http://www.awesomium.net"/> </Grid> </Window>

member.name: P:Awesomium.Windows.Data.SourceBinding.DoNotHandleUserInput
member.summary: Gets or sets if the should deactivate any manipulation of the bound element. The default value is false, which means that the will regularly manipulate the bound , to make it act as a web address-box.
member.remarks:
If this is set to true, the will not monitor user input and will not perform any manipulation of the bound , other than binding its property to the property of the source web-view.
No explicit updating of the source and target properties will be applied. Updating of the property will fall back to , which means that the property will be updated every time you edit the contents of the , irrespective of user input (updating will not wait for the user to hit Return).
Focus toggling, selecting of contents and other features will also be deactivated.
Setting to true can be useful if you are binding the property of a read-only (see ).

member.name: T:Awesomium.Windows.Data.UriValueConverter
member.summary: Provides a way to apply custom conversion logic to a .
member.remarks:
This value converter can convert a from and to . You can use it in your own bindings.
An instance of this value converter is applied by default to instances of , when no custom converter is specified through .
You can create your own custom URI converter deriving and overriding or . You can then assign this converter to , along with any parameter you need to be passed to it.
This allows you to add custom logic on how a converts and passes a URI to and from a .

This helper method sets the main culture, UI culture and the language of FrameworkElements specified in XAML.
The method must be called from the UI thread, before (if explicitly called) or before the creation of the first or web-view component ( or other).
The current culture affects the locale of Awesomium.NET UI elements (such as context menus) and the locale of integrated JavaScript frameworks (such as PDF.js).
The current culture is also returned from the JavaScript navigator.language property.
member.returns: true if the culture was successfully set; false otherwise. The method can return false if for example the application's is not created yet or if the application has been shut down.

member.summary: Gets or sets the to use with the created session.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Windows.Controls.WebSessionProvider.DataPath
member.summary: Gets or sets the disk data path of this session, if any.
member.remarks:
Leave this empty to create an in-memory .
If another using the same data path has previously been created, the will provide the previous session, instead of creating a new one. In this case, any preferences defined in , are ignored.
This prevents exceptions that would occur when more than one s attempt to access the same data store. This feature also provides an easy way to re-use an on-diskÂ with multiple instances residing on different WPF containers: Just specify the same on all your s and they will all provide the same session.
For more details, read: Using Web-Sessions
